On the other hand, pasteurized milk is subjected to high heat, which can destroy not only harmful pathogens but also many of the naturally occurring enzymes, vitamins, and beneficial bacteria that are present in raw milk.

In terms of safety, raw milk is often misunderstood. When sourced from clean, healthy animals raised on pasture with proper handling and hygiene, raw milk is perfectly safe to consume. In fact, numerous studies and historical data show that properly handled raw milk has a strong safety record. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and other regulatory bodies tend to focus on rare outbreak cases, but that’s not a reflection of the overall safety of raw milk when handled responsibly.

It also contains naturally occurring probiotics, which support gut health and immune function. These beneficial bacteria are often destroyed during pasteurization. Additionally, raw milk has higher levels of certain vitamins, such as B12, folate, and enzymes like immunoglobulins that support the immune system.

Many people who switch to raw milk report improved digestion, better tolerance to dairy, and even fewer allergies or asthma symptoms. These anecdotal reports are supported by the presence of bioactive components in raw milk that may have anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties.

So, in summary, raw milk is not only safe when properly handled, but it also offers a more complete and biologically active nutritional profile compared to pasteurized milk. It’s a whole food in its most natural state, and that makes it a healthier choice for those who have access to quality, locally produced raw milk.
